hawaiian_text: Ho'ouna maila 'o 'Ama'u ke ali'i mai Waikīkī mai, 'ehā po'e kaua, aia ma ka po'e ho'okahi he kanahā kumamāwalu kānaka ka nui, pēlā ā pau nā po'e 'ehā. A hiki lākou ma ke kula o Keahumoa, komo lākou ā loko o ka hale, 'a'ohe kanaka. A mākaukau lākou e ho'i, kāhea mai 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o i luna o kaupoku. A lohe lākou i ka leo, 'a'ohe na'e he 'ike 'ia o ke kino, nīnau aku lākou: "'Auhea 'oe e wala'au nei?" 'Ī mai 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o: "Eia nō wau i luna nei." Pi'i a'ela 'ewalu kānaka, 'ehā ma ke kua o ka hale, 'ehā ma ke alo o ka hale ā loa'a 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o. 'Ī mai 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o: "He aha mai nei kā 'oukou o 'one'i?" 'Ī aku lākou: "I hele mai nei mākou e kaua me Nāmakaokapāo'o, he wahi keiki 'u'uku e like me 'oe, he ikaika a me ke koa loa, nāna nō i pepehi i kona makua kāne, 'o Puali'i."
gpt-4_1_translation: ‘Ama‘u, the chief from Waikīkī, sent four warriors, each with a group of forty-eight men, so that all four groups together were the same. When they reached the plain of Keahumoa, they entered the house but found no one inside. As they were preparing to leave, Nāmakaokapāo‘o called out from above the rooftop. When they heard the voice, but saw no body, they asked, “Where are you, you who are speaking?” Nāmakaokapāo‘o replied, “Here I am up here.” Eight men climbed up—four at the back of the house, four at the front—until they found Nāmakaokapāo‘o. Nāmakaokapāo‘o said, “What brings you here?” They answered, “We have come to fight Nāmakaokapāo‘o, a little child like you, very strong and brave, who has slain his own father, Puali‘i.”
gpt-4_1_commentary: **Paragraph 8:**• This paragraph is a digression from the story to clarify  that Nā-maka-o-ka-lani (the eyes of the heavens) and  Nā-maka-o-ka-i‘a (the eyes of the fish/man) are two  names used in the lyrics of the prayer chant. Nā maka-o-ka-lani defeats Nā-maka-o-ka-i‘a in the prose,  symbolically representing the defeat of the ‘Ai Kapu  by Christianity.
raw_response:
<translation>
‘Ama‘u, the chief from Waikīkī, sent four warriors, each with a group of forty-eight men, so that all four groups together were the same. When they reached the plain of Keahumoa, they entered the house but found no one inside. As they were preparing to leave, Nāmakaokapāo‘o called out from above the rooftop. When they heard the voice, but saw no body, they asked, “Where are you, you who are speaking?” Nāmakaokapāo‘o replied, “Here I am up here.” Eight men climbed up—four at the back of the house, four at the front—until they found Nāmakaokapāo‘o. Nāmakaokapāo‘o said, “What brings you here?” They answered, “We have come to fight Nāmakaokapāo‘o, a little child like you, very strong and brave, who has slain his own father, Puali‘i.”
</translation>

<commentary>
**Narrative and Cultural Analysis:**
• **Introduction of Opposing Forces:**  
  – The passage marks the mobilization of significant martial force: ‘Ama‘u (ʻa-maʻu, perhaps “the fern” or a chiefly name derived from a fern, symbolic of resilience and regality) from **Waikīkī** (well-known as a seat of aliʻi power in traditional Oʻahu society) dispatches four groups of warriors, each containing forty-eight men (kanahā kumamāwalu = 48). The use of this specific number is notable and may carry symbolic meaning—multiples of four and the number forty-eight frequently appear as significant, cosmologically resonant numbers in Polynesian cultures. Their repetition across the four groups (totaling 192 men) symbolizes completeness and martial rigor, implying a formally sanctioned military action rather than an impromptu raid.

• **Setting and Action:**
  – The warriors travel to **Keahumoa** (“the chicken heap,” a dry plain inland of Honouliuli, often portrayed in tradition as a place of contest and transformation), and upon entering the house, find it empty. This moment of emptiness and anticipation builds narrative tension, emphasizing the house not simply as a residence but as a stage for confrontation and potential transformation.

• **Supernatural or Heroic Concealment:**  
  – Nāmakaokapāo‘o reveals himself only by voice, calling from atop the rooftop (kaupoku), which is both a literal vantage point and a metaphorical assertion of higher status, perspective, or spiritual potency. The device of the voice heard but body unseen evokes a motif common in Hawaiian mo‘olelo, where heroes, demigods, or supernatural children display powers of concealment, ventriloquism, or telepresence—often as a test for lesser mortals. His refusal to show himself immediately parallels the actions of kupua (shape-shifters or demigods), suggesting his unique status.

• **Dialogue and Challenge:**
  – The elite group of eight men (a highly tapu, or sacred, number, often referencing cardinal points, completeness, or the duality of male and female in traditional counting or organizing) split up to encircle and locate the boy—four in front, four in back—underscoring methodical, ritual encirclement as might be used in battle or in ritual capture of a supernatural being. Such spatial arrangements also resonate with the kapu system, where specific protocols dictated how approach to sacred individuals or spaces must be made.

  – Upon being found, Nāmakaokapāoʻo calmly demands their purpose, demonstrating youthful fearlessness and authority—consistent with previous descriptions of his unmatched bravery and perhaps divine parentage.

• **Accusation and Reputation:**  
  – The warriors’ answer summarizes the growing legend of Nāmakaokapāo‘o: a small child (keiki ‘u‘uku), exceptionally strong and brave (ikaika a me ke koa loa), but also ominously, the one who killed his own father (kona makua kāne, ʻo Puali‘i).  
    – Patricide in Hawaiian narrative is extremely rare and often considered kapu in itself, carrying heavy allegorical significance. It marks Nāmakaokapāo‘o as both an outlaw and a transformative agent, upending the established order (potentially referencing historical disruption of the 'Ai Kapu religious system or the rise of new chiefly lines defeating old ones).
    – This charge also signals to the audience the gravity of the warriors’ mission—it is not merely a battle of equals but a retributive, purificatory act ordered by a higher chief (‘Ama‘u of Waikīkī), meant to quell an existential threat to the social and moral order.

• **Symbolic and Etymological Notes:**
  – **Nāmakaokapāo‘o** (Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o): “the eyes of the pāo‘o fish.” The pāo‘o is a small, dark fish known for its persistence and agility in rocky tide pools, a metaphor for resourcefulness, survival, and obscurity. “Eyes” (*maka*) often symbolize vision, insight, or a watchful nature. As in earlier passages, this name, linked with current action—being unseen yet present, “seeing” all from above—reinforces the child’s supernatural attributes.
  – **Puali‘i:** The slain father—the name connotes “descendant/child of a chief,” amplifying the gravity of the killing as not only an act against a parent but a crime against high rank.

• **Allegorical and Moral Interpretation:**
  – This episode frames Nāmakaokapāo‘o as occupying a liminal, or boundary, status: he is both hale (of the house) but also apart (on the roof, unseen), both child (keiki ‘u‘uku) and killer, both feared and sought out by great warriors. Thus, he embodies paradox and transformation.  
    – The story here allegorizes the disruption of established social orders, possibly signifying a shift in religious or political power (cf. upheavals at the end of the 'Ai Kapu period or during major chiefly wars).  
    – The number symbolism and coordinated military engagement may indicate the ritual seriousness with which breaches of kapu or social order were met—in this case, the warriors are not mere avengers but agents of restoration.

• **Conclusion—Narrative Function:**
  – This passage expertly weaves martial organization, supernatural motifs, and deep cultural anxieties about order and transgression. It sets the stage for a confrontation that is not only physical but cosmological and moral. The careful unfolding of dialogue and group action displays the classic structure of Hawaiian epic, balancing individual mana (spiritual power) with collective authority, and foreshadows a test of status, right, and survival.
</commentary>
reference_translation: Chief 'Ama'u sent four regiments of soldiers from Waikīkī totalling forty-eight men. When they reached the plains of Keahumoa, they entered the house, but no one was there. When they were ready to return back to Waikīkī, Nāmakaokapāo'o called out from on top of the roof. They heard the voice, but didn't see any body, and they asked, "Where is that voice coming from?" Nāmakaokapāo'o said, "I'm up here." Eight men climbed up, four men went onto the roof and four on the face of the house and got a hold of Nāmakaokapāo'o. Nāmakaokapāo'o said, "What in the world are you all doing here?" They said, "We came to fight Nāmakaokapāo'o, a little boy like you, who is really strong and brave. He killed his father, Puali'i."
reference_commentary: **Paragraphs 10—14** • From here, the story seems to extend the allegory of Christianity's defeat over the 'Ai Kapu, with Nāmakaokapāo'o representing progressive Protestant Christianity and everyone apart from his mother, Pōka'ī, and himself, representing Hawaiians' futile attempts to hold onto 'Ai Kapu culture.
